content.text:
​ ************************************* READ ME ************************************* 

 

I am writing this work online and public, so anyone who can offer me  

improvements can notify it through the Google comments system. 

 
 

************************************* Work in Progress ************************************* 
 

 

* All sources * 
http://tinyurl.com/iskandaranidrive 

 
Google Drive: [ÆTHER VORTEX] 

   

- The theoretical foundation of the non-viscous liquid Aether -  
- by O. Iskandarani 

 

http://tinyurl.com/iskandaranidrive
https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B2EtTZsfgoFUfnZBZm1XaUVtYUFhMDRHSE9GRGpKb2FzT3NnZzF2UUtHRjlHeTZjSUFBNEk&usp=sharing


 

 

-The theoretical foundation of the non-viscous liquid Æther-  

 
- Fundamental considerations for the theory of the liquid æther - 

 
 
  

 
Glossary of the incompressible non-viscous liquid Æther. 

 
* Vortex * 

 Mass of liquid in a vortex or circular motion 
* Vortex Line * 

A line of particles with parallel vorticity vector 
* Vortex Tube * 

 A surface filled with vortex lines 
* Vorticity  * 

Local rotation of a velocity vector 
* Circulation * 

Integral along the tangential component 
* Rotation * 

Circular rotational movement about an axis 
 
 

 
 

* Trefoil Knot*   

-The theoretical foundation of the non-viscous liquid Æther-  
- by ​O. Iskandarani. -  



 

 

-The theoretical foundation of the non-viscous liquid Æther-  

 

 

Introduction 
The theory presented in the following pages, includes the most common form of what is today                               
called the "æther theory." I have given this name because the term æther has been used since                                 
ancient times for what we now call the vacuum. In this work I try to describe the vacuum as a                                       
flow of a non-viscous 'superfluid' æther. The conviction for this concept came after studying                           
the original works of J.C.Maxwel​l​[ ]​, H.Helmholtz​[ ] & A.Einstein​[ ]​. Atoms in this model are vortex                           1 2 3

currents of the æther, as suggested by W.Thomson​[ ]​. It is known that the Special Theory of                               4

Relativity by Einstein​[ ] ​complements the Dynamic Theory of the Electromagnetic Field Maxwell​[                     5 6

]​,a theory of simultaneous actions of bodies at a distance in electrical and magnetic                           
experiments. In this model we will not continue in the dynamical theory, but in the theory of                                 
Molecular Vortices by J.C.Maxwell, in which we try to translate the laws of the general theory                               
of relativity and modern physics into a liquid æther, where accelerations are the fundamental                           
forces of nature. A vortex is a mass of liquid æther in circular motion, whereby in the case of an                                       
atom, there is a small vortex knot​[ ] ​contained in the center, which represents a core with its                                 7

own course of time in this model, by means of vortex circulation. In addition, we will attempt to                                   
explain heat in this model by means of the swelling of the elastic spherical equilibrium                             
conditions of vortex atoms, as represented by W. Thomson. 
I'm going to try to explain the concept of relative time-space in terms of relative vorticity of the                                     

liquid æther. In this work, Part I will present the basic considerations, I will try to make this as                                     
simple as possible so that it is not necessary that the reader master the mathematics to                               
understand this model. In Part II, I describe the mathematical introduction for this model. In this                               
work I try to establish the basis for a complete non-viscous liquid æther theory that should give                                 
physicists a visual image to the experience of inertia for atoms. Short summary that applies for                               
the nucleus of an atom: 
 

 ​Experienced Time = Core vorticity  

 

1  J.C.Maxwell, On Physical Lines of Force. Philosophical Magazine, VOL XXI 
2  H. von Helmholtz, On Integrals of the Hydrodynamic Equations That Correspond to Vortex 
Motions,1858 
3  A.Einstein, The Foundation of the General Theory of Relativity, 1916, 
4  W.Thomson, (lord Kelvin) On Vortex Atoms, 1867 
5  A.Einstein, 1905: ‘Over de elektrodynamica van lichamen in beweging’  Annalen der Physik, 17 
6  J.C. Maxwell, A Dynamical Theorie of the Electromagnetic Field. Royal Society Transactions, VOL clv 
7  W.Thomson, (lord Kelvin) Vortex statics. Proc. R. Soc. Edinburgh 9, 59–73 

-The theoretical foundation of the non-viscous liquid Æther-  
- by ​O. Iskandarani. -  



 

 

-The theoretical foundation of the non-viscous liquid Æther-  

Part I: 
Fundamental Considerations for the liquid æther theorem  

 
§1. The demand for an extension for the propositions of physics 
Any serious consideration for a physical theory must take into account the difference between                             

objective reality, which is independent of a theory, and the physicist statements containing the                           
theory. These statements are intended to correspond to objective reality and it is on the basis                               
of these statements that we  try to make a reality for ourselves. 
The modern scientific understanding of reality comes from the Theory of Relativity and Modern                             
Physics. When we ask ourselves whether the descriptions of these theories is complete, we                           
should keep in mind that this applies to specific strictly defined conditions, namely the                           
characteristics of clocks and measuring rods and the statistical behavior of electrons. The                         
general theory of relativity nor modern physics describe the objective reality of the æther. The                             
theory of relativity meets excellent at describing the rotation of the hands of a clock and will on                                   
account for practical reasons probably never be replaced by another theory. 
In special relativity, the term "simultaneously" is defined with the synchronous positions of the                             

hands of multiple clocks and receiving the light emitted between the clock. We will have to                               
adapt this definition of the simultaneity, because of the fact that quantum entanglement                         
suggest that the mechanical information of the æther can surpass the speed of light. 
The model of a non-viscous liquid æther states that the different time experienced by atoms,                               

which is noticed by the no longer synchronous pointers of the clocks, is defined as the                               
difference in the rotation of the vortex knots. The nucleus of the atom in our model is the                                   
spherical equilibrium of pressure around a rotating vortex knot, in which we have for the                             
nucleus of the hydrogen atom, today known as the proton, the simplest vortex knot named the                               
three-fold "Trefoil knot". The tangential velocity at the edge of the vortex is the highest velocity                               
for æther particles in a vortex or the particles associated with the vortex.  
 
§2. Observations on the Theory of Relativity 
General relativity is formulated so that it does not preclude a light carrying æther, but it                               
heuristically explains the behaviour of the æther in terms of time, space and matter with mass.                               
Einstein taught us that mass can bend particle trajectories in the so-called time-space,                         
because of this fact the vacuum appears to be unanchored in the absolute empty                           
three-dimensional space and thus appears to have physical properties, which are directly                       
related to the experience of space and time for matter. In this model we assume that there                                 
exists a potential flow of æther particles between two identical uniformly moving atoms, which                           
connects the two atoms together in the experience of space and time. We consider this                             
potential flow between two vortex knots as a single vortex, of which the vortex line on the                                 
z-axis acts as the rotary connecting shaft. We assume that each atom has a physical                             
connection to another atom by means of vortex lines through the æther. This means that                             
identical moving vortex knots must have an identical value to the core rotation and tangential                             
velocity component. 
 
   

-The theoretical foundation of the non-viscous liquid Æther-  
- by ​O. Iskandarani. -  



 

 

-The theoretical foundation of the non-viscous liquid Æther-  

§3. Observations on Light Particles 
The atom constantly transmits light, thus losing internal energy. We consider the light quanta                           
as a flow of æther particles, which are moving as a rolling ring vortex at a constant rate,                                   
however, these vortices can have different sizes of cross sections and frequencies. A vortex                           
always connect to a surface of the liquid or back on itself. In the latter case, if a vortex is not                                         
knotted, the vortex is a vortex ring (torus), also known as a dipole of which the total energy of                                     
the flow is determined by the amount of æther particles fixed in rotation in the vortex and its                                   
tangential velocity. 

If in a fluid the effects of diffusion and viscous forces are negligibly small, which we assume in                                     
our assertion of a liquid æther, then the fluid will be taken along in a moving vortex, wherein the                                     
æther particles which originally residing in the core of the vortex remain in the vortex. This                               
means that æther vortices can move mass, momentum and energy over vast distances, as                           
opposed to surface and pressure waves. Thus the light particle is a torus shaped vortex, the                               
dipole. When viewed in a section the dipole consists of two superposed vortex tubes. Both                             
vortices have an equal radius and an opposite tangential velocity component. One vortex with                           
the circulation force M at position -R, the other vortex with circulation force -M at position R,                                 
both vortices with an equal radius r, which move forward through the æther with a translatory                               
velocity equal to the tangential velocity component of the vortex, with the proviso that R = r.                                 
The path of particle on the edge of a torus can be seen in x,y,z coordinates as a functions of,  

 vortex circulation and ring rotation  
 
where the position of the particles are subject to the coordinates of the torus by,

Mathematical Introduction 

§4. The use of the differential equation  
In the liquid aether theorem we use the the sub-area of mathematics called analysis, which                             
extends through Calculus involved with the change of functions, as occur in infinitesimal                         
changes. If one grants an increase to a variable and allows it to increase to near zero we call                                     
this the differential of ​x (notation ). We begin by way of example with the differential                               
equation of the arbitrary functions ​ф​ (x, y) and ​φ​ (x, y)

§5. Movement of free aether particles 
The aether is a homogeneous incompressible non-viscous liquid. This means that the æther                         
consists of perfect solid spherical particles, which has no change in the density ​ρ​. The amount                               
of mass per unit volume will always stay the same. 
 

 
We choose a coordinate system which is fixedly anchored in the absolute space, in our case a                                 
Cartesian (x, y, z) system. The æther is moving relative to this coordinate system. All the                               
variables of interest are then functions of the three coordinates ​x​, ​y​, ​z and the absolute time t​.                                   
The absolute background space, wherein the æther is contained consists of three spacial                         
dimensions with an absolute one directional period of time. The absolute background space                         
knows no relative time. This view for atoms is replaced by the constant vorticity of an atom and                                   
the relative vorticity of another atom. Important factors are: the pressure ​P where ​P​xx

§7. Definition of vorticity for æther particles.  
An irrotational flow is a potential flow, ie a flow in which all particles move in parallel particle

From the document you've provided, "The Theoretical Foundation of the Non-Viscous Liquid Æther" by O. Iskandarani, I see that the model described aligns closely with the framework you're developing, specifically involving the properties of vortices in a non-viscous, incompressible Æther.

### Adding Insights from Iskandarani's Æther Theory
Here are some intriguing concepts from Iskandarani's work that could be beneficial to incorporate:

#### 1. **Vorticity and the Concept of Relative Time**
Iskandarani describes atoms as vortex currents in the Æther, with their core vorticity representing their experienced time. This aligns well with your model, where vorticity imbalance between different vortex knots represents local variations in time perception. Specifically, Iskandarani proposes that the different experienced times of atoms are defined by differences in vortex rotation. Thus, relative vorticity between knotted vortices in different spheres of pressure equilibrium could be interpreted as the source of time differentiation in your model.

This provides a theoretical basis for modeling how local time emerges from vorticity in an absolute Æther, bypassing the need for relativistic frameworks. By focusing on how vorticity differences influence local time, you can establish a direct analogy between rotational dynamics of vortex knots and the passage of time, allowing for a consistent, Euclidean interpretation of temporal flow.

#### 2. **Solid Vortex and Energy Relationships**
The work describes solid vortices, specifically in the context of incompressible Æther, where each vortex knot can be represented by a solid core surrounded by circulating Æther. The kinetic energy associated with these vortices is expressed as:
\[
E_{\text{vortex}} = \frac{1}{2} M R^2 \Omega^2,
\]
where \( M \) is the mass of the vortex, \( R \) is the radius, and \( \Omega \) is the angular velocity. The tangential velocity at the edge of the vortex reaches a maximum for the Æther particles associated with the vortex.

In your model, this energy formulation could represent the energy contained within each vortex knot, giving a quantifiable relationship for how the vortex behaves dynamically within its pressure equilibrium sphere. Since the tangential velocity is associated with the perceived constant between time and space, this provides a direct way to quantify how energy and local vorticity translate into time dynamics.

#### 3. **Potential Flow and Irrotational Æther**
Iskandarani's description of potential flow as a rotation-free or irrotational motion within the Æther could also fit into your framework. In regions of flat space—represented as undisturbed Æther—the flow is irrotational, meaning that these areas act as potential flows where the Æther is uniform and undisturbed by vortex knots. This fits with your description of flat space as potential flow, where streamlines are equivalent to vortex threads.

The potential flow description of flat space means that, mathematically, these regions can be modeled using potential functions (\( \Phi \)) where:
\[
\mathbf{v} = \nabla \Phi,
\]
and the irrotational nature implies \( \nabla \times \mathbf{v} = 0 \). This suggests a foundational difference between the regions with vortex structures (knotted vortices contributing to local vorticity and therefore local time) and regions where the Æther is undisturbed.

#### 4. **Interaction Through Vortex Lines**
The document describes how vortex lines can act as connections between atoms or particles, implying that all matter is interconnected via these vortex structures. This could be used to represent how particles interact through vorticity-induced strain fields in your model. Specifically, two trefoil knots positioned along the z-axis, with one moving toward the other, could represent a dynamic interaction where the influence of planetary vorticity (as external vorticity) affects the relative vorticity of the approaching knot. This interaction could lead to an exchange or alignment of vorticity that influences how these knots perceive time, effectively creating a dynamic model of temporal exchange through vorticity interactions.

#### 5. **Vortex Stability and Spherical Pressure Equilibrium**
The stability of vortex knots within spheres of equilibrium pressure can be further elaborated using Iskandarani's idea of elastic spherical equilibrium. Each knot maintains a balance of pressure with respect to the surrounding Æther, meaning that any disturbance (such as vorticity imbalance) will lead to a compensatory flow, either through attraction or repulsion of neighboring knots. This could model the gravitational or electromagnetic-like interactions in your framework. The pressure difference resulting from a higher or lower vorticity region can drive these flows, providing a natural mechanism for attraction or repulsion without invoking the conventional concept of gravitational force.

#### 6. **Mathematical Formulation of Relative Vorticity**
To model the relative vorticity between two knotted vortices:
- **Planetary Vorticity (\( \omega_p \))** represents the vorticity of the stationary knot (e.g., at \( (0,0,0) \)).
- **Relative Vorticity (\( \omega_r \))** represents the vorticity of the moving knot along the z-axis (e.g., at \( (0,0,z) \)).

Using relative vorticity principles similar to fluid dynamics:
\[
\text{Relative Vorticity } (\omega_{\text{rel}}) = \omega_r - \omega_p.
\]
This differential vorticity can then influence the local dynamics, such as the strain rate and corresponding flow, providing a mechanism to describe how the local time of each vortex knot adjusts based on the external and internal vorticity fields.

### Summary of Potential Additions
1. **Helicity and Vorticity Dynamics**: Integrate helicity conservation and reconnection dynamics from recent vortex knot studies, focusing on how these influence the stability and energy distribution of knotted vortices.
2. **Vorticity and Time Relationship**: Explicitly relate core vorticity to experienced time, as derived from Iskandarani's description of atoms as vortex knots with distinct rotation dynamics.
3. **Potential Flow and Irrotational Regions**: Clarify that flat, irrotational regions of the Æther act as potential flows, which are undisturbed and serve as the "flat space" in your model.
4. **Interactions via Vortex Lines**: Describe the interactions of vortex knots through connecting vortex lines, emphasizing relative vorticity as a mechanism for time differentiation.
5. **Elastic Spherical Pressure Equilibrium**: Use the concept of spherical equilibrium to explain how knotted vortices maintain stability and how disturbances propagate as vorticity-induced flows.
6. **Relative and Planetary Vorticity Dynamics**: Employ relative vorticity to explain how different vortex knots influence each other and adjust local time, incorporating mathematical expressions that quantify these effects.

These additions should enrich the theoretical foundation of your Luminous Æther model, providing a more rigorous and interconnected understanding of how vorticity, time, and energy manifest within an absolute Euclidean framework. Would you like me to expand on any of these ideas or provide more detailed mathematical derivations?

It seems you are elaborating on a very detailed setup of how vorticity in a superfluid Æther could relate to time perception through the interaction of vortex knots, specifically using the trefoil knot as a stable configuration. Let me expand upon and integrate these insights into your existing document to further deepen the model.

### Expanding on the Luminous Æther Model with Vorticity Dynamics and Trefoil Knots

In this expanded description, we'll incorporate some new concepts, specifically focusing on the interaction between knotted vortices (using trefoil knots as the basis) and how these interactions might influence local time perception. The idea is that by understanding the dynamics of vorticity within this superfluid Æther, we can provide a more detailed framework for how time emerges as a result of vorticity differences. This extension also uses classical fluid dynamics principles—namely planetary and relative vorticity—to explain the observed behaviors.

#### Trefoil Knots as Stable Vortex Structures

In the Luminous Æther model, vortex knots are key to understanding matter, interactions, and time. The **trefoil knot**, being the simplest nontrivial knot, is assumed to be the first stable vortex structure. This trefoil knot resides in our 3D Euclidean space at location \((0,0,0)\), with the **z-axis** passing through its central hole.

The central assumptions regarding these vortex knots are:
1. **Rotation within the Knot**: The core of the trefoil knot can rotate along the **x-y plane**, while the three "wings" of the knot can rotate or revolve around the **z-axis**. This dual rotation scheme creates a complex dynamic system where different parts of the knot can carry distinct vorticity values.
2. **Vorticity and Local Time Perception**: The rotation and revolution of these vortex structures give rise to a local perception of time. Local time in this context is defined by the number of revolutions or rotations of the knotted vortex, essentially representing how many times the vortex moves through a complete cycle.

#### Dynamics of Two Interacting Trefoil Knots

To understand the interaction between two such knots, consider placing a **second trefoil knot** along the z-axis at location \((0,0,z)\). Moving this knot along the z-axis toward \((0,0,0)\), we introduce relative and planetary vorticity effects:

1. **Planetary Vorticity of the Fixed Knot** (\(0,0,0\)):
   - The trefoil knot positioned at the origin has an intrinsic rotational velocity due to the properties of the surrounding Æther. This velocity contributes to its **planetary vorticity**, which is effectively a measure of the vorticity inherent to the knot itself within the overall undisturbed Æther.
   - This planetary vorticity acts like a "reference frame" for other vortex structures moving through the Æther.

2. **Relative Vorticity of the Moving Knot** (\(0,0,z\)):
   - The second knot, which is moved along the z-axis, experiences **relative vorticity** based on its movement with respect to the planetary vorticity of the original knot.
   - The relative vorticity \(\omega_{\text{rel}}\) can be defined as:
     \[
     \omega_{\text{rel}} = \omega_r - \omega_p,
     \]
     where:
     - \(\omega_r\) is the vorticity of the moving knot.
     - \(\omega_p\) is the planetary vorticity of the fixed knot.

This **vorticity imbalance** leads to differential strain or pressure within the Æther, manifesting as a change in the local vorticity between the two trefoil knots. This dynamic could affect the internal energy of the knots, as well as their "local time" as perceived by their internal rotation states.

#### Vorticity, Pressure, and Local Time Dynamics

In the Æther model, interactions are not explained by gravitational force in the classical sense but instead arise from pressure gradients and vorticity differences in the surrounding Æther:

1. **Vorticity and Pressure Relationships**:
   - Higher vorticity in a region implies increased kinetic energy and lower pressure.
   - Conversely, regions of lower vorticity may have higher pressure.
   - When two vortex knots interact, these pressure differences drive their relative motions, creating either attraction or repulsion based on their vorticity states. The higher the vorticity imbalance, the stronger the resulting differential pressure, which influences how the knots move relative to one another.

2. **Connection to Local Time**:
   - The local time experienced by each knot is influenced by these vorticity dynamics. For example, as the second knot approaches the first, the **relative vorticity** increases. This could be interpreted as a compression of time or an acceleration in the local temporal flow due to increased rotational interactions.
   - The **perception of time** within the core of each vortex knot is thus not absolute but varies based on the surrounding Æther's vorticity field. As a vortex knot moves through areas of varying external vorticity, its internal rate of rotation (and hence its local clock) changes.

#### The Fabric of Time-Space in Vortex Threads

The concept of time-space as an unbreakable fabric formed by parallel vortex threads can also be expanded:

- The vortex threads represent **potential flow lines** in regions of flat space where no knotted vortices disturb the Æther.
- These threads create a framework for **absolute time**, which is maintained as long as the threads remain undisturbed. However, when interactions between vortex knots occur, such as when vorticity imbalance arises, it leads to local disturbances in this "fabric," effectively altering the rate of time for those interacting elements.

To integrate this into a mathematical model:
- The **velocity potential** \( \Phi \) and **stream function** \( \psi \) can be employed to represent the irrotational flow of Æther between vortex knots.
- In cylindrical coordinates \((r, \theta, z)\), with the z-axis representing the axis along which the vortex knots align, the velocity components can be expressed as:
  \[
  v_r = -\frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial \theta}, \quad v_\theta = \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial r}, \quad v_z = \frac{\partial \Phi}{\partial z},
  \]
  where \(\psi\) remains constant along streamlines, representing the vortex threads that form the time-space fabric.

These streamlines represent the unbroken time-space fabric in regions devoid of strong vorticity. However, in the presence of vortex knots, these streamlines are distorted, and their connectivity changes, leading to temporal shifts and potential energy redistribution.

#### Helicity and Knotted Vortex Dynamics

The **helicity** of a vortex knot provides another interesting avenue for expansion. Helicity, defined as:
\[
H = \int_V \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{\omega} \, dV,
\]
where \(\mathbf{v}\) is the velocity field and \(\mathbf{\omega}\) is the vorticity field, measures the degree of knottedness or linkage of vortex lines.

- In the Luminous Æther model, **helicity** is conserved in ideal conditions, which implies that the knotted structures maintain their coherence as they interact, unless reconnection occurs.
- When helicity dissipation does occur, such as during a vortex reconnection event, the result could be a temporary alteration in the local temporal flow—a form of "temporal turbulence." The reconnection of knotted vortices might release energy, impacting the local Æther pressure and vorticity, hence altering the perceived time in the surrounding region.

The concept of **super-helicity hotspots**, where reconnection occurs and helicity dissipates intensely, can be used to represent **localized temporal disturbances** in the Æther. These disturbances are analogous to a "ripple" in the fabric of time-space, caused by rapid changes in vorticity during the reconnection process.

### Summary of Expanded Concepts
1. **Trefoil Knots and Vorticity as a Basis for Local Time**:
   - The interaction between stable trefoil knots provides a mechanism for local time variation based on planetary and relative vorticity dynamics.
   - Moving vortex knots adjust their local rotational state according to the external vorticity, thereby experiencing changes in local time.

2. **Pressure Gradients and Æther Dynamics**:
   - Differential pressure in the Æther, resulting from vorticity imbalance, drives the movement and interaction of vortex knots. These pressure-induced flows create either attractive or repulsive forces, leading to the dynamic rearrangement of knots.

3. **Time-Space Fabric and Potential Flow**:
   - The undisturbed regions of Æther represent potential flows, providing a stable framework for absolute time. Disturbances, caused by vortex knots, alter the time-space fabric, leading to localized variations in the flow of time.

4. **Helicity and Temporal Disturbances**:
   - Helicity is an important quantity representing the knottedness of the vortex structures. Reconnection of vortex knots can lead to helicity dissipation, causing localized temporal disturbances akin to temporal turbulence.

These additions further solidify the theoretical foundation of your Luminous Æther model, integrating physical, mathematical, and conceptual insights that deepen the understanding of vorticity-driven time perception and interactions between stable vortex structures. Local time in this context is defined by the number of revolutions or rotations of the knotted vortex, essentially representing how many times the vortex moves through a complete cycle.

#### Dynamics of Two Interacting Trefoil Knots

To understand the interaction between two such knots, consider placing a **second trefoil knot** along the z-axis at location \((0,0,z)\). Moving this knot along the z-axis toward \((0,0,0)\), we introduce relative and planetary vorticity effects:

1. **Planetary Vorticity of the Fixed Knot** (\(0,0,0\)):
   - The trefoil knot positioned at the origin has an intrinsic rotational velocity due to the properties of the surrounding Æther. This velocity contributes to its **planetary vorticity**, which is effectively a measure of the vorticity inherent to the knot itself within the overall undisturbed Æther.
   - This planetary vorticity acts like a "reference frame" for other vortex structures moving through the Æther.

2. **Relative Vorticity of the Moving Knot** (\(0,0,z\)):
   - The second knot, which is moved along the z-axis, experiences **relative vorticity** based on its movement with respect to the planetary vorticity of the original knot.
   - The relative vorticity \(\omega_{	ext{rel}}\) can be defined as:
     \[ \omega_{	ext{rel}} = \omega_r - \omega_p, \]
     where:
     - \(\omega_r\) is the vorticity of the moving knot.
     - \(\omega_p\) is the planetary vorticity of the fixed knot.

This **vorticity imbalance** leads to differential strain or pressure within the Æther, manifesting as a change in the local vorticity between the two trefoil knots. This dynamic could affect the internal energy of the knots, as well as their "local time" as perceived by their internal rotation states.

#### Vorticity, Pressure, and Local Time Dynamics

In the Æther model, interactions are not explained by gravitational force in the classical sense but instead arise from pressure gradients and vorticity differences in the surrounding Æther:

1. **Vorticity and Pressure Relationships**:
   - Higher vorticity in a region implies increased kinetic energy and lower pressure.
   - Conversely, regions of lower vorticity may have higher pressure.
   - When two vortex knots interact, these pressure differences drive their relative motions, creating either attraction or repulsion based on their vorticity states. The higher the vorticity imbalance, the stronger the resulting differential pressure, which influences how the knots move relative to one another.

2. **Connection to Local Time**:
   - The local time experienced by each knot is influenced by these vorticity dynamics. For example, as the second knot approaches the first, the **relative vorticity** increases. This could be interpreted as a compression of time or an acceleration in the local temporal flow due to increased rotational interactions.
   - The **perception of time** within the core of each vortex knot is thus not absolute but varies based on the surrounding Æther's vorticity field. As a vortex knot moves through areas of varying external vorticity, its internal rate of rotation (and hence its local clock) changes.

#### The Fabric of Time-Space in Vortex Threads

The concept of time-space as an unbreakable fabric formed by parallel vortex threads can also be expanded:

- The vortex threads represent **potential flow lines** in regions of flat space where no knotted vortices disturb the Æther.
- These threads create a framework for **absolute time**, which is maintained as long as the threads remain undisturbed. However, when interactions between vortex knots occur, such as when vorticity imbalance arises, it leads to local disturbances in this "fabric," effectively altering the rate of time for those interacting elements.

To integrate this into a mathematical model:
- The **velocity potential** \( \Phi \) and **stream function** \( \psi \) can be employed to represent the irrotational flow of Æther between vortex knots.

  where \(\psi\) remains constant along streamlines, representing the vortex threads that form the time-space fabric.

The paper **"A New Relativistic Theory for Modified Newtonian Dynamics"** discusses an alternative approach to gravity, aiming to explain the observed galactic accelerations without relying on dark matter. The theory is built around Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND), initially proposed by Milgrom to address discrepancies in star motion in galaxies, particularly where observed accelerations deviate from those predicted by Newtonian gravity.

Key elements of the theory include:
1. **MOND Dynamics:** The paper introduces a relativistic MOND theory that is consistent with both galactic observations and key cosmological phenomena, such as the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) and the matter power spectra (MPS). Traditional MOND is a non-relativistic theory, so the authors address this by expanding it into a relativistic framework.
2. **Phenomenology:** The theory reproduces the known galactic and lensing behaviors of MOND and aligns with cosmological observations, filling gaps that earlier versions of MOND failed to address. The authors argue that their formulation preserves the successes of general relativity (GR) at large scales but modifies it at the smaller, galactic scale to explain phenomena without invoking dark matter.
3. **Cosmic Structure Formation:** The paper also explores how the theory impacts cosmological structure formation, aiming to address issues like the formation of galaxies during the early universe and maintaining consistency with the CMB data.

This theory avoids "ghost instabilities" (which are problematic unphysical solutions) and seeks to provide a robust alternative to both dark matter and dark energy explanations.

For further exploration, the authors discuss potential links between this framework and more fundamental theories, possibly connecting with ideas from higher-dimensional theories like string theory.

The theory offers a fresh perspective on gravity, modifying how we understand galactic dynamics and cosmological evolution without the need for unseen dark matter.

The given equation:

\[
\frac{D \vec{U}}{D t} = \frac{1}{\rho} \nabla P - \nabla \phi_g - \nabla \frac{\omega^2 r^2}{2} - 2 \vec{\omega} \times \vec{u}
\]

represents the **momentum balance** for a rotating fluid in the context of a rotating reference frame. This is essentially an adaptation of the **Navier-Stokes** or **Euler equations** to include the effects of a rotating frame of reference. Let’s break down each term in this equation:

1. **Material Derivative of Velocity (\( \frac{D \vec{U}}{D t} \))**: 
   - This term represents the **total acceleration** of a fluid parcel. It includes both the local time rate of change of velocity and the convective component that accounts for changes due to motion within a velocity field.
   
2. **Pressure Gradient Force (\( \frac{1}{\rho} \nabla P \))**: 
   - This term is the **pressure gradient** divided by the density \( \rho \), representing the force per unit volume acting on the fluid due to differences in pressure.

3. **Gravitational Potential Gradient (\( - \nabla \phi_g \))**: 
   - Here, \( \phi_g \) is the **gravitational potential**. The negative gradient, \( -\nabla \phi_g \), represents the **force due to gravity** acting in the direction of decreasing gravitational potential.

4. **Centrifugal Potential Gradient (\( - \nabla \frac{\omega^2 r^2}{2} \))**: 
   - The term \( \omega^2 r^2 / 2 \) represents the **centrifugal potential** in a rotating frame. The gradient \( - \nabla (\omega^2 r^2 / 2) \) captures the **centrifugal force** that acts outward from the axis of rotation. It arises due to the rotation rate \( \omega \) and the distance \( r \) from the rotation axis.

5. **Coriolis Force (\( - 2 \vec{\omega} \times \vec{u} \))**: 
   - This term represents the **Coriolis force** that acts on a fluid element in a rotating reference frame. Here:
     - \( \vec{\omega} \) is the **angular velocity vector** of the rotating frame.
     - \( \vec{u} \) is the **velocity** of the fluid element relative to the rotating reference frame.
     - The cross product \( 2 \vec{\omega} \times \vec{u} \) represents the Coriolis acceleration, which is proportional to both the velocity and the angular velocity. It is directed orthogonally to both, influencing the deflection direction of the fluid movement.

### Physical Interpretation

- **Frame of Reference**: This equation is used for a rotating reference frame, such as the atmosphere on a rotating planet like Earth, or a fluid inside a rotating mechanical system.
- **Forces at Play**:
  - The equation balances the **forces acting on the fluid element**, including pressure, gravitational force, centrifugal, and Coriolis forces.
  - The **centrifugal force** term, \( \nabla \frac{\omega^2 r^2}{2} \), counteracts the inward acceleration that would be experienced by the rotating fluid, whereas the **Coriolis force** term, \( -2 \vec{\omega} \times \vec{u} \), leads to a deflection of the fluid depending on the direction of motion relative to the rotation.
  
### Applications

- **Geophysical Fluid Dynamics**: This type of equation is fundamental in modeling large-scale motions in the Earth's atmosphere and oceans, where rotation is a key factor.
- **Rotating Systems**: This can also be applied to other rotating systems, like turbines, centrifuges, and astrophysical contexts (e.g., rotating stars or planets).

In summary, the given equation is a form of the **momentum equation for a fluid in a rotating frame**. It accounts for pressure-driven forces, gravitational effects, and the inertial forces (centrifugal and Coriolis) arising due to rotation. The equation is central in describing the behavior of rotating fluids in planetary atmospheres, engineering, and astrophysical systems.

In the presence of **vorticity**, particularly if the vortices are "rolling," they generate a **local velocity field** that bends the neighboring streamlines. This creates a pattern around the vortex, showing a rolling or spiral effect rather than straight flow lines.

- **Vortex Influence in Flat Fluid**: In a flat fluid with initial equilibrium, adding vortices means that some fluid parcels will move in response to the velocity induced by the vorticity. The Coriolis and centrifugal forces further complicate these motions, generating deviations from what would be simple, straight streamlines in the absence of any such vorticity.

Thus, the equation you've provided is a **dynamical equation** that determines the forces acting on the fluid, which indirectly determines how streamlines are shaped. To **visualize streamlines** influenced by vorticity, one typically needs to solve for the **velocity field** and use that to plot the paths of fluid elements. The equation you provided resembles the form of the **Schwarzschild metric** in general relativity, which describes the geometry of spacetime around a non-rotating, spherically symmetric mass. This metric is used to describe how spacetime is curved by the presence of a mass such as a planet or a star, and it’s fundamental in describing phenomena like black holes.

To **mimic** the given metric in a flat fluid dynamics situation, we need to approach it using concepts from vorticity, flow lines, and potential theory. Here’s a breakdown of how we could conceptually align such a metric with the Luminous Æther model:

### Original Metric and Its Components
The Schwarzschild metric is typically expressed as:
\[
ds^2 = \left(1 - \frac{r_s}{r}\right)c^2 dt^2 - \left(1 - \frac{r_s}{r}\right)^{-1} dr^2 - r^2 (d\theta^2 + \sin^2 \theta d\phi^2)
\]
Where:
- \( r_s = \frac{2GM}{c^2} \) is the **Schwarzschild radius**.
- \( ds^2 \) is the **invariant interval** (a measure of spacetime distance).
- The differentials \( dt, dr, d\theta, d\phi \) represent **time**, **radial distance**, and **angular components**.

### Mimicking the Metric in Fluid Dynamics
To approximate this in a flat fluid dynamics scenario with Æther-like properties, we consider a few main components:

1. **Potential Flow and Vorticity as Spacetime Curvature Analogue**:
    - The gravitational potential in general relativity can be mimicked by an **effective potential** in the fluid, often represented by pressure gradients or induced vorticity.
    - The **vorticity** or velocity circulation in a fluid could serve as the analogue of the **curved spacetime** around a mass. The idea would be to represent the gravitational influence through velocity potential and vorticity balance.

2. **Effective Metric Representation**:
    - The metric element analogous to \( \left(1 - \frac{r_s}{r}\right) c^2 dt^2 \) could be represented by a term involving **pressure and velocity potentials** in the fluid flow. In particular, pressure differentials and the velocity field could be used to approximate how time would be experienced differently in a non-uniform flow.
    - A potential velocity field in the Æther model, represented by \(\phi_{\text{fluid}}\), could be introduced:
    \[
    ds^2 = \left(1 - \frac{\phi_{\text{fluid}}}{c^2}\right) c^2 dt^2 - \left(1 - \frac{\phi_{\text{fluid}}}{c^2}\right)^{-1} dr^2 - r^2 (d\theta^2 + \sin^2 \theta d\phi^2)
    \]
    - Here, \(\phi_{\text{fluid}}\) represents the **velocity potential** induced by vorticity or an equivalent pressure gradient, acting like the gravitational potential.

3. **Rotational and Radial Components**:
    - In the Luminous Æther model, we could consider the **radial dependence** to correspond to the distance from a stable vortex knot. This would align with how the metric describes the influence of gravity weakening with distance.
    - The differential elements \( d\theta \) and \( d\phi \) relate to the angular position around a vortex knot. This represents how flow properties, including vorticity and velocity, change based on the spherical geometry centered on a vortex knot.

4. **Introducing Fluid Velocity and Pressure**:
    - The effective velocity around a vortex could act analogously to the **curvature** induced by mass. For example, the **Coriolis term** or centrifugal effects could represent rotational influences similar to frame dragging in rotating bodies.
    - The velocity potential \(\phi_{\text{fluid}}\) could be defined as:
    \[
    \phi_{\text{fluid}} = -\frac{\omega^2 r^2}{2} + \phi_g + P/\rho
    \]
    where:
    - \( -\frac{\omega^2 r^2}{2} \) represents **centrifugal potential**.
    - \( \phi_g \) represents a potential analogous to **gravitational potential**.
    - \( P/\rho \) represents a pressure contribution that would influence the flow similar to how mass-energy influences spacetime curvature.

5. **Time Dilation Analogy**:
    - In the gravitational context, **time dilation** occurs due to the warping of spacetime by a mass. In the Æther model, time dilation could be modeled by the influence of **vorticity** on local flow lines. 
    - Specifically, regions of **higher vorticity** might represent **slower time** (similar to a stronger gravitational field), while regions with **lower vorticity** allow for faster progression of time.

### Conclusion
The equation provided for \( ds^2 \), which represents a curved spacetime metric, could be mimicked in fluid dynamics by using concepts from **potential flow theory**, **vorticity**, and **pressure distribution** in the Æther. The velocity potential acts similarly to the gravitational potential, and the influence of rotation and pressure in the fluid provides a curvature analogue that impacts the effective flow.

This approach is still a conceptual approximation, as fluid dynamics and general relativity are fundamentally different frameworks. However, by aligning the effects of **vorticity, velocity potentials, and pressure gradients** with gravitational curvature, you can mimic how spacetime behaves around a mass using the behavior of a rotating superfluid Æther. This idea fits well into the broader context of the Luminous Æther model, where vorticity and pressure interplay to simulate forces and temporal effects analogous to those in general relativity.

- **Knotted Vortices**: Vortex knots are topological configurations that maintain **stability** through their knotted nature.
- **Equilibrium Spheres**: Surrounding each knotted vortex is a sphere of **equilibrium pressure**, which can expand or contract depending on **heat transfer** into or out of the system.

1. **Internal Energy (U)**: The **internal energy** in this model corresponds to the **kinetic energy** of the knotted vortices plus the **pressure-volume work** of the surrounding equilibrium spheres. 2. **Heat (Q)** and **Work (W)**: 
   - **Heat (Q)** is associated with the energy transfer that causes the **swelling** of the equilibrium spheres, which, in turn, impacts the **local vorticity**.
   - **Work (W)** reflects the **pressure-volume changes** of these spheres. As the vortices change configuration, the work done on or by the system affects its thermodynamic state.

3. **Entropy (S)**: **Entropy** measures the **disorder** or **irreversibility** linked to the configuration changes of vortex knots and their equilibrium spheres. As the spheres **swell** or **contract**, and as vortex knots **evolve** or undergo **reconnection events**, entropy quantifies the resulting disorder and the loss of useful energy in the system.

#### Mathematical Integration with Clausius’s Framework

We reinterpret **Clausius’s equations** in this new context:

1. **First Law of Thermodynamics**: The **first law** now encompasses both the **kinetic energy** of vortex motion and the **volume change** of equilibrium spheres.

The change in entropy represents both the **thermal disorder** and the **topological complexity** of the vortex system.

#### Practical Applications: Heating and Cooling Vortex Systems

Consider a scenario where a system of **vortex knots** is **heated** or **cooled**:
- **Heating**: As thermal energy is added, the **spheres of equilibrium pressure** surrounding the vortex knots **swell**, increasing their volume. This leads to a decrease in local vorticity and an increase in **internal energy**, similar to gases expanding when heated.

  "content": "### Mathematical Framework for the Unified Vortex Knot-Thermodynamics Model

To express the Æther model mathematically, we will describe the **vorticity fields** and develop a system of differential equations governing the behavior of **vortex knots** and **pressure equilibrium spheres**. The primary components and relationships involved are:

#### 1. **Vorticity Fields**

The vorticity field, denoted by \( \vec{\omega} \), represents the rotational motion around each vortex knot:

\[
\vec{\omega} = \nabla \times \vec{v}
\]

where \( \vec{v} \) is the velocity field of the fluid representing the Æther. Vorticity in this context measures the tendency of fluid elements to spin about an axis, which is fundamental in defining the behavior of vortex knots in the Æther.

#### 2. **Conservation of Total Vorticity**

The conservation of total vorticity is a key principle in the Æther model, expressed as:

\[
\int_{A} \vec{\omega} \cdot d\vec{A} = \text{constant}
\]

This integral ensures that the **net absolute vorticity** remains unchanged over the entire system. Here, the area integral is taken over a closed surface surrounding each vortex knot or pressure sphere, indicating that the circulation of vorticity in a closed system is conserved.

#### 3. **Local Time and Vorticity Gradient**

The concept of **local time** \( t_{\text{local}} \) is influenced by the **vorticity gradient** within the pressure equilibrium sphere surrounding each vortex knot. We represent local time as a function of the vorticity gradient:

\[
 t_{\text{local}} = f(\nabla \omega)
\]

Here, \( \nabla \omega \) describes the rate of change of vorticity across the boundary of the sphere. Differences in the local vorticity affect the perception of time at the particle level, providing a local time flow that varies with the distribution of vorticity.

#### 4. **Pressure Equilibrium and Vorticity Relationship**

The pressure equilibrium at the surface of each sphere is a function of the local vorticity, represented by:

\[
 P_{\text{eq}} = f(\omega)
\]

where \( P_{\text{eq}} \) is the equilibrium pressure and \( \omega \) is the local vorticity at the boundary of the sphere. This relationship indicates that the equilibrium pressure at the sphere’s boundary is directly influenced by the rotational energy of the vortex knots.

#### 5. **Absolute and Local Time Concepts**

- **Absolute Time**: Represented by constant vorticity lines that form a **vorticity lattice** through which vortex knots exist. This lattice is stable and forms the basis for a fundamental, invariant flow of time across the entire system.

- **Local Time**: The differences in vorticity across **pressure equilibrium spheres** provide localized variations in time flow, denoted by \( t_{\text{local}} \). The gradient of vorticity between knots affects the local perception of time, with higher gradients resulting in more pronounced differences in time flow.

#### 6. **Mathematical Derivations and Dynamics**

##### a. **Navier-Stokes Equation with Vorticity Term**

To incorporate the effects of vorticity, we start with the Navier-Stokes equation, incorporating the vorticity explicitly:

\[
 \frac{D \vec{v}}{D t} = -\nabla P + \nu \nabla^2 \vec{v} + \vec{F}_{\text{ext}}
\]

Taking the curl of both sides yields an equation for the evolution of vorticity:

\[
 \frac{D \vec{\omega}}{D t} = (\vec{\omega} \cdot \nabla) \vec{v} - \nu \nabla \times (\nabla \times \vec{v})
\]

This describes how vorticity evolves within the fluid (Æther) and interacts with other vortices, influencing local pressure fields and hence local time.

##### b. **Pressure-Vorticity Relationship and Equilibrium**

The equilibrium condition for the pressure around a vortex knot can be expressed by balancing the vorticity-induced pressure with the external Æther pressure. Assuming an idealized form:

\[
 P_{\text{eq}} = P_{0} - \frac{1}{2} \rho \vec{\omega} \cdot \vec{r}
\]

where \( P_0 \) is the reference pressure, \( \rho \) is the fluid density, and \( \vec{r} \) is the radial vector from the center of the vortex knot. This shows that pressure drops in regions of high vorticity, leading to the characteristic pressure equilibrium surrounding each vortex knot.

##### c. **Vorticity Interaction and Local Time Evolution**

Local time evolution depends on the interaction between neighboring vorticity fields. If two adjacent vortex knots have differing vorticities \( \omega_1 \) and \( \omega_2 \), the local time difference \( \Delta t_{\text{local}} \) can be modeled as:

\[
 \Delta t_{\text{local}} = C \cdot (\omega_2 - \omega_1) \cdot \nabla P
\]

where \( C \) is a proportionality constant that depends on the properties of the Æther. This implies that local time progresses differently based on the relative differences in vorticity between adjacent equilibrium spheres, creating regions of faster or slower time flow within the Æther system.

##### d. **Conservation of Angular Momentum in Vortex Knots**

For each vortex knot, conservation of angular momentum must be maintained. The angular momentum \( L \) of a vortex knot is given by:

\[
 L = \int_{V} \rho (\vec{r} \times \vec{v}) \, dV
\]

Considering a knot with time-evolving vorticity, we have:

\[
 \frac{dL}{dt} = \int_{V} \rho \left( \vec{r} \times \frac{D \vec{v}}{D t} \right) dV = 0
\]

This condition ensures the stability of knotted vortices, meaning that without external influence, the internal angular momentum of the knot remains conserved, contributing to the persistence of equilibrium spheres.

### Summary of Mathematical Framework

- **Vorticity Field**: Describes the rotational properties of vortex knots, governed by \( \vec{\omega} = \nabla \times \vec{v} \).
- **Conservation of Total Vorticity**: The total circulation in the system is preserved, ensuring no net change in absolute vorticity.
- **Local Time Dependence**: Local time \( t_{\text{local}} \) is influenced by the gradient of vorticity within the pressure equilibrium spheres.
- **Pressure Equilibrium Relation**: Pressure at the boundary of each sphere depends on local vorticity \( P_{\text{eq}} = f(\omega) \).
- **Navier-Stokes with Vorticity**: Used to derive the dynamic evolution of vorticity in the Æther.
- **Angular Momentum Conservation**: Ensures the stability of the vortex knots, linking vorticity to the persistence of equilibrium spheres.

These mathematical formulations aim to provide a consistent theoretical framework that captures the interplay between **vorticity**, **pressure**, and **local time** within the proposed unified vortex knot-thermodynamics model."}

Dynamics of a Vortex Ring in a Rotating Fluid 

PROEFSCHRIFT 

ter verkrijging van de graad van doctor aan 
de Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, op gezag 
van de Rector Magnificus, prof.dr. M. Rem, 
voor een commissie aangewezen door het College 
van Dekanen in het openbaar te verdedigen op

geboren te Maastricht 



Dit proefschrift is goedgekeurd door de promotoren:

en 
prof.dr.ir. M.E.H. van Dongen 



WOORD VOORAF 

In dit proefschrift staan de resultaten vermeld van het onderzoek dat ik de afgelopen jaren 
heb uitgevoerd in het kader van mijn promotie. Het woord 'ik' in de vorige zin wekt misschien 
de gedachte op dat ik vier jaar lang ergens in mijn eentje heb zitten spelen met wervelringen 
en nu de resultaten hier presenteer. Het tegendeel is waar. Veel mensen hebben bijgedragen 
aan het onderzoek dat uiteindelijk geleid heeft tot dit proefschrift. Graag wil ik deze mensen 
hiervoor bedanken. 

Dit promotie-onderzoek is mogelijk gemaakt door GertJan van Heijst, waarvoor ik hem 
zeer dankbaar ben. Dankzij hem ben ik ook in contact gekomen met een aantal mensen die 
een belangrijke bijdrage hebben geleverd aan dit onderzoek. First I want to thank Roberto 
Verzicco (Universita di Roma "La Sapienza") for the pleasure collaboration we had last years 
that resulted in two detailed studies on the motion of a vortex ring in a rotating fluid. He 
has developed the numerical codes that were used in the simulations, which were very useful 
for this research. His stimulating help has contributed significantly to the results described in 
this thesis. Verder wil ik Paul van Enckevort bedanken die tijdens zijn afstudeeronderzoek, 
en enkele maanden daarna, zeer vele experimenten heeft uitgevoerd. Vaak was hij degene 
die dagen bezig was een nieuwe opstelling op te bouwen en liet dan vervolgens mij het eerste 
wervelringetje afschieten. I would like to thank Shura Gourjii to provide the numerical code 
to perform the simulations with Dyson's model and his assistance in the study of the coaxial 
motion of vortex and vorton rings. I am grateful to Gianni Pedrizzetti for providing his 
numerical code to perform three-dimensional vorton ring simulations. Verder heeft het enthou­
siasme van Slava Meleshko voor de beweging van wervelringen mij voortdurend gestimuleerd 
in dit onderzoek. Ik kreeg van hem altijd meer artikelen dan ik kon verwerken, zodoende ligt 
er nog een stapel klaar voor rustigere tijden. 

Jan van Dijk, Jos Mettler, Frank Toonen en Tony Vandeweijer ben ik dankbaar voor de 
bijdrage die zij aan dit onderzoek hebben geleverd tijdens hun stage. Jullie vragen hebben 

vaak aan het denken gezet. 
Verder wil ik mijn kamergenoten Marcel Beckers, Johan van de Konijnenberg, Oscar Ve­

lasco Fuentes en Pauline Vosbeek bedanken voor de fijne tijd die we samen hebben gehad en 
de hulp en steun bij het oplossen van kleine en grote problemen tijdens het onderzoek. Jos 
van Geffen, bedankt voor de lekkere koffie en de gezelligheid iedere ochtend. 

Jan van Asten wil ik bedanken voor het maken van maar liefst twee wervelring generatoren. 
Voor de verdere technische ondersteuning van de laboratorium experimenten ben ik Harm 
Jager, Eep van Voorthuisen en Jan Willems dankbaar. Allieten de wervelringen zich vaak 
moeilijk fotograferen, het is toch gelukt om ze te 'vangen': Erwin, bedaank! Een voorbeeld van 
zo'n foto is te zien op de voorzijde van dit proefschrift. Gert van der Plas ben ik dankbaar voor 
zijn hulp als de computers niet deden wat ik graag wilde dat ze deden. Ruben Trieling wil ik 
bedanken voor de zeer nuttige software om experimentele data te analyseren. Ion Barosan was 



altijd direct bereid te helpen als ik vragen had met betrekking tot de software om numerieke 
simulaties te visualizeren, waarvoor mijn dank. Herman Clercx wil ik bedanken voor het 
oplossen van storingen in het computernetwerk en voor het gebruik van zijn 'rekenkracht' om 
enkele zware numerieke simulaties uit te voeren. 

Ik wil prof. M.E.H. van Dongen, prof. F.T.M. Nieuwstadt en prof. V.V. Meleshko bedanken 
voor het lezen van dit proefschrift en het plaatsen van kritische opmerkingen die me op het 
laatste moment nog even goed aan het denken hebben gezet. GertJan, bedankt voor het snel 
en zorgvuldig nalezen van de tekst en het opsporen van vele type- en spelfouten. 

Ik wil mijn lieve vrouw Yvonne bedanken die ervoor gezorgd heeft dat ik ook nog een ander 
Ieven had dan aileen maar onderzoek doen. Zij wa..s 's avonds als ik thuiskwam vaak in staat 
om mijn gedachten binnen enkele minuten om te zetten van wervelringen naar allerdaagse 
dingen. Lieve meid, al dreigden de wervelringen in de laatste weken alsnog onze huiskamer 
binnen te komen, zet het raam maar open dan gaan ze vanzelf weer naar buiten. Mijn ouders 
wil ik bedanken voor de goede zorg gedurende mijn studie en het eerste gedeelte van het 
promotie-onderzoek. 

In het laatste stadium van het onderzoek, tijdens het schrijven van dit proefschrift, hebben 
vele mensen mij enorm gesteund en ik ben daar iedereen hartelijk dankbaar voor. 

MENNO EISENGA 

Eindhoven, 7 april 1997 



Hoe simpellijkt de eenvoud, 
hoe complex kan die zijn. 

(Yvonne)

1 

GENERAL INTRODUCTION 

Vortex rings are best known as the thin rings of smoke that are formed by blowing gently a 
gust of smoke; the thick smoke of a cigar is excellent for this purpose. Taking a close look at 
the structure of this flow, it is seen that the smoke inside the ring-shaped core rotates around 
the core. As a consequence of this intrinsic swirling flow the vortex ring propagates by its 
own self-propelling mechanism, in a direction normal to the plane of the ring. Vortex rings 
can be observed in several practical circumstances, although they are not always visible or 
just appear accidentally. A drop of water falling in a glass of water generates a vortex ring 
propagating downwards, but this vortex ring is invisible unless the water drop is dyed; e.g. 
by some milk. Occasionally, a vortex ring can also be observed in the puffs of steam from the 
chimney of a steam locomotive or a steam boat, rising several tenth of meters with a diameter 
expanding to more than one meter. Very large vortex rings are the typical mushroom-shaped 
cloud observed in an explosion or a volcano eruption. A very harmful kind of vortex ring 
structure, especially a hazard to aircraft, is a microburst, which occurs when a downdraft 
of dense air suddently falls to Earth and spreads outward along the Earth's surface with a 
horizontal extent of several kilometers (Fujita, 1981 ). Recently, it has been observed that 
dolphins can create vortex rings very consciously by slamming their fins and visualize them 
by breathing small air bubbles in the ring core (Marten et al. 1996). Also by blowing air from 
their blowholes the dolphins can create vortex rings and sometimes they are observed to swim 
through the rings in a playful way. 

These are just a few examples of more or less natural circumstances in which vortex rings 
appear. It is nice to notice that vortex rings are used or have been attempted to use in 
several technological applications. For example, vortex rings have been suggested as a means 
for extinguishing gas and oil well fires (Akhmetov et al. 1990) and cavitating vortex rings, 
produced by exciting cavitating jets, have been used for underwater cleaning and rock cutting 
(Chahine & Genoux 1983). In addition, vortex rings have been proposed to transport industrial 
wastes to high altitudes (Turner 1960) and, recently, the US Army Research Laboratory 
conducts a research to the feasibility of using high velocity (~ 200 m/s) ring vortices for 
non-lethal riot control at stone throwing ranges (50 ~ 100m). 

It should be stressed that it is not because of these practical examples that vortex rings 
have been studied so extensively for more than one century. The attention for vortex rings is 
initiated by the work of Helmholtz (1858) on general vorticity dynamics and Kelvin's theory 
of vortex ring atoms (Thomson 1867b ). In the last three decades the vortex ring has been 
the subject of many fundamental studies. A vortex ring is commonly considered to be an 

3 



4 General introduction 

elementary vortical structure that, although it has a simple symmetric structure, possesses 
many properties that apply also to more complicated three-dimensional vortices. Due to the 
axisymmetric stable nature of vortex rings their flow structure can be analyzed in detail and 
they are easily generated experimentally. 

A few examples of studies in which vortex rings are used to gain insight in basic vorticity 
mechanisms are mentioned here. The interaction of two vortex rings involves many important 
processes related to vorticity dynamics, like deformations of the vortex core, vorticity can­
cellation and merging, change of the topology of vortex lines and intense vortex stretching. 
Several kinds of interaction of vortex rings have been studied, among which the periodical 
leapfrog motion of two coaxially interacting vortex rings placed in tandem is a classical exam­
ple (see Yamada & Matsui 1978 for an experimental demonstration of this interaction). The 
collision of two inclined vortex rings fusing into one big ring (see e.g. Schatzle 1987) has been 
studied to gain insight in the reconnection mechanism by which the topology of vortex lines 
changes due to viscous processes. The reconnection mechanism is also an important process 
in the dynamics of magnetic flux tubes in plasma's and of quantized vortices in superfluid 
helium. Insight in specific features of the dynamics of coherent vortices (e.g. hairpin vortices) 
in turbulent boundary layers (an overview of which is given in Robinson, 1991) is acquired by 
investigation of the impact of a single vortex ring with a solid wall (see Walker et al. 1987 and 
Verzicco & Orlandi 1996b for overviews). 

In most studies the vortex ring is generated in a fluid at rest. It is obvious that in an 
ambient shearing flow the vortex ring is deformed according to the local shearing rate (Meng 
1978). In general a shearing background flow consists of both a straining and a rotational 
component. To study these effects separately, the vortex ring is best examined in a fluid 
containing only one of these two components. In this thesis the effect of the rotation of an 
ambient flow on the propagation and dynamics of a vortex ring is examined. 

Flows affected by a background rotation appear in many practical circumstances. Geo­
physical flows in the atmosphere and ocean are, among buoyancy effects due to stratification, 
dominated by the rotation of the Earth. Also flows in turbomachinery and cyclone separators 
are just a few examples in which the main background swirl is dominant. A very important 
feature in these flows is the anisotropy, as variations in the flow motion along the rotation 
axis are prohibited when the rotation is sufficiently strong. In a bounded region this means 
that the flow motion along the rotation axis is suppressed and the main flow evolves into a 
two-dimensional motion in a plane normal to this axis. In addition, the energy of the flow 
is transfered to larger scales, resulting in the formation of large coherent vortices typical of 
two-dimensional turbulence. 

Flows with a uniform background rotation are best examined relative to a co rotating frame 
of reference. The relative flow in such a rotating system is then affected by Coriolis forces 
which are imposed by the system rotation and tend to deflect all motion in a plane normal 
to the rotation axis in a direction opposite to the sense of rotation of the system. In terms 
of vorticity, the background rotation represents a permanent present uniform vorticity field 
directed along the rotation axis, that interferes with the vorticity of the relative fluid flow. 
This background vorticity acts as a persisting source by which relative vorticity can be induced 
in regions of the relative flow that are initially in irrotational motion. As a consequence, flows 
relative to a rotating system are commonly endowed by relative vorticity. The mechanisms 
by which relative vorticity is induced and the interaction between the induced vorticity and 
the vorticity of the main relative flow are processes that are of significant importance in the 



General introduction 5 

dynamics of rotating flow systems. Elementary insight in these processes is indispensable to 
gain a proper comprehension of the evolution of such rotating flows. 

To study these processes in detail a relative flow has to be considered with a well-defined 
initial structure. A vortex ring is for this purpose an excellent candidate. The structure of a 
vortex ring is compact, robust and symmetric and the vortex lines form closed circles around 
the axis of symmetry. Owing to the initial 'simple' structure of a vortex ring the analysis 
of the development of the flow can be pursued in detail, yielding a thorough insight in the 
induction and dynamics of relative vorticity in rotating systems. 

The main part of this thesis concerns a study of the evolution of a vortex ring that is 
generated in a fluid in uniform rotation. Basically, two cases can be distinguished. In the 
first case the vortex ring is initially directed along the axis of rotation and in the second case 
the ring is directed perpendicular to this axis. Both cases are studied separately, revealing 
flow patterns that are specific for either case. The development of the flow depends on the 
rotation rate of the system. The appropriate dimensionless parameter is the Rossby number 
that measures the relative importance of inertial forces to Coriolis forces. This parameters 
is defined by Ro = U /2fl£, where (U and £ are typical velocity and length scales of the 
relative flow, respectively, and n is the angular velocity of the rotation. For low rotation 
rates ( Ro » 1) the relative flow is slightly perturbed by the background rotation, while for 
small Ro-values (Ro « 1) the background rotation dominates the flow motion. For different 
rotation rates the formation and propagation of vortex rings have been examined, showing a 
different evolution of the flow for low and high rotation rates. 

The investigations are based on both laboratory experiments and numerical simulations 
that are used as complementary tools. For the laboratory experiments a vortex ring generator 
was designed and tested to check its reproducibility to generate vortex rings with repeatedly 
the same characteristics for definite injection parameters. These tests and characterizations 
have been performed for a vortex ring generated in a fluid at rest and the results are discussed 
in chapter 2. The propagation of a vortex ring in a rotating fluid is investigated in the next 
two chapters, the case that the vortex ring is directed along the axis of rotation is considered in 
chapter 3 and the case of the vortex ring fired perpendicular to the rotation axis in chapter 4. 
In these studies numerical simulations have been helpful in order to get a complete picture 
of the flow evolution. Special care has been taken to ensure that the simulations mimic the 
laboratory experiments in the same range of flow parameters. 

In the final chapter a study is presented that is completely different from the previous ones. 
In this study a comparative analysis has been performed between two inviscid flow models 
describing the coaxial interaction of two vortex rings. One of these models, the vorton model 
(Novikov 1983), was originally supposed to be suitable for studying the motion of a vortex ring 
in a rotating fluid. Before doing this, however, this model has been subjected to a thorough 
analysis, because many drawbacks are inherent to this model. The analysis is based on the 
classical leapfrogging motion and provides insight in the drawbacks of the vorton model in 
relation to the Dyson model (Dyson 1893) that is better founded physically. 

The study in chapter 3 has already been publish~d (see Verzicco et al. 1996) in a some­
what condensed version. Chapters 4 and 5 have been submitted for publication. The main 
conclusions of the investigations presented in this thesis are summarized in chapter 6. 



6 General introduction 



2 

CHARACTERISTICS OF VORTEX RINGS 

2.1 Introduction 

This chapter describes experimental investigations of the flow structure of vortex rings gener­
ated in a fluid at rest. The vortex rings were created by injection of fluid through a circular 
orifice on top of a cylindrical box. This generation technique is well known and has already 
been used in previous studies (see e.g. Maxworthy 1972; Glezer 1988). The characteristic flow 
parameters of the produced vortex rings are affected by the mechanism of fluid injection and 
the configuration of the vortex ring generator. Therefore, comparison of ring parameters of 
vortex rings produced in different experimental arrangements is often very difficult. One of 
the parameters of the fluid injection that is difficult to fix in most vortex generator designs 
is the time evolution of the injected fluid slug. For convenience, one commonly assumes a 
uniform flow profile of the fluid injection, but it has been shown by Didden (1977) that for 
different injection flow profiles the ring parameters were not the same. 

For the experiments presented in this thesis a very simple vortex ring generator has been 
constructed in which the fluid injection was provided by several syringes that are pressed 
by a step-motor driven traversing system. Although the amount of injected fluid and the 
mean injection velocity could be well established, the shape of the injection profile was just 
approximately uniform. Since no experience was available with this new design, the vortex ring 
generator and injection mechanism had to be tested first to check whether the created vortex 
rings have repeatedly the same characteristic ring parameters. To measure these parameters 
two kinds of flow visualization techniques were used. Visualizations with dye provided a clear 
insight in·ttre·fotmation and subsequent evolution of the vortex ring and whether the flow 
field is laminar or turbulent is obviously inferred. In addition, a method was developed to 
deduce from these dye visualizations values for the characteristic ring parameters. In the 
second visualization technique the velocity field induced by the vortex ring is measured by 
tracking the motion of small tracer particles. In these experiments the specific structure of 
the vortex ring flow is measured from which the various ring parameters can be deduced. 
Both visualization techniques have been used as complementary tools to gather a complete 
characterization of the produced vortex rings. The experimental set-up and data processing 
techniques are described in section 2.3 and the results of the experiments are presented in 
section 2.4. 

Because of the steady structure of vortex rings theoretical models are commonly based 
on inviscid flow assumptions. In section 2.2 several vortex ring models are presented, which 

7 



8 Characteristics of vortex rings 

are well-known from literature. In most of these models the vortex ring is assumed to have 
a simple (ideal) structure and an expression is derived for the velocity of propagation of the 
vortex ring in terms of the dimensions of the and the strength of the vortex. The effects 
of viscosity in real fluids on the structure of vortex rings are briefly discussed. The chapter 
ends with a summary of the main conclusions (section 2.5).

2.2.2 MODELS OF INVISCID VORTEX RINGS 

A vortex ring in an ideal fluid at rest at infinity has an axisymmetric ring-shaped structure. 
The vorticity is concentrated in the core of the ring, there is no swirling motion along the 
core and the vortex linest are closed circular loops. Such a vortex ring propagates due to its 
self-induced motion in a direction perpendicular to the plane of the ring, without changing in 
size or shape. 

To describe the structure of the vortex ring mathematically, cylindrical coordinates (r, ¢>, z) 
are used, with the z-axis coinciding with the centreline of the ring and oriented in the direction 
of propagation. The velocity field induced by the vortex ring can be written in terms of a 
Stokes stream function 1/J (see equation (2.1)) and the vorticity in the core has only a non-zero 
azimuthal component. Relative to a frame moving with the ring the flow field is steady and a 
relation of the form of equation (2.5) applies to the vorticity distribution in the vortex core. 

Several theoretical models for steady inviscid vortex rings have been proposed in the liter­
ature, since the celebrated works of Helmholtz (1858) and Thomson (1867b; 1869) on vortex

12 Characteristics of vortex rings 

Despite these mathematical derivations, it is also possible to provide a more physical 
explanation for the self-induced velocity of a thin-core vortex ring by considering the force 
balance acting on the curved vortex. In simple terms it is proposed that adding curvature 
to a straight vortex filament leads to an increase in the velocity on the 'inside' of the curve 
and a related reduction of the pressure. Oppositely, at the 'outside' of the curve the velocity 
decreases and the pressure is increased. The resulting pressure force is equivalent to a tension 
of the curved vortex and is directed toward the ring centre. In the absence of an additional 
external flow this force has a tendency to shrink the vortex ring. This shrinking would reduce 
the vortex ring's impulse, being proportional to the square of the ring radius (Batchelor 1967, 
p. 522). The fluid impulse, defined as the resultant force impulse required to generate the flow 
of the vortex ring from rest, is a conserved quantity in an infinite flow domain (Batchelor 1967, 
p. 520). Therefore, an additional force is required to keep the ring radius constant and the 
flow steady. This counter force is provided by a Kutta lift force, generated by the external flow 
that encounters the vortex ring as it propagates through the surrounding fluid. A complete 
derivation for the propagation velocity based on this approach is given in Moore & Saffman 
(1972) (see also Saffman 1992). '
